The Wimblestone.name: The Wimblestone
The Wimblestone.description: A triangular shaped standing stone 1.8m tall with a hole through it, near Winscombe in Somerset. Additional stones were thought to have once been nearby. Local traditions state there is a treasure hidden beneath the stone and that the stone walks when it either hears the clock strike twelve or between the hours of midnight and dawn and it is said that during its nocturnal wanderings a heap of shining gold has been seen glistening in the moonlight. Allegedly a farmer once tried to remove it with chains and two horses but failed.

Triscombe Stone.name: Triscombe Stone
Triscombe Stone.description: The Triscombe Stone probably dates from the Bronze age. It marks a meeting place on the old drovers' road along the Quantock hills in Somerset, between Watchet and Lyme Regis. It has recently been given its own little timber circle to protect it from cars. Modern superstitions about the stone include, if you sit on it, you will be granted a wish.

Stanton Drew SSW.name: Stanton Drew SSW
Stanton Drew SSW.description: The fallen remains of a stone circle on a small plateau overlooking the main Stanton Drew circles and surrounding landscape. Circle diameter: 44m (145 feet). Number of stones remaining: 10 out of a possible 12 ?

East Pinford 2.name: East Pinford 2
East Pinford 2.description: Said to be a six stone rectangle similar, but less distinct, to East Pinford 1, with only one stone still standing. I certainly found a stone standing at the grid ref noted here, about 0.3 metres high. There are a lot of other stones laying around on the surface, but I could not really determine any shape or form amongst them.

Wells Cathedral.name: Wells Cathedral
Wells Cathedral.description: Early Christian Sculptured Stone in Somerset

Yenworthy.name: Yenworthy
Yenworthy.description: A lovely pair of standing stones, each about a metre tall, stood about 30 metres from each other, to the east and almost at the top of the hill opposite County Gate car park on Exmoor. These stones stand near to the remains of two round barrows, which may or may not be contemporary with them.

Fromefield Stones.name: Fromefield Stones
Fromefield Stones.description: Three standing blocks of stone possibly connected to a long barrow excavated in 1965. The existing stones lie at the top right hand side of a wide driveway leading to Leystones, Bath Rd. These stones do not seem to appear in the historical record before the 1930s and their origin & purpose remain unknown.

Wavering Down cairn.name: Wavering Down cairn
Wavering Down cairn.description: Remains of a round cairn on the top of Wavering Down, at the western end of the Mendip Hills.

Plainsfield Camp.name: Plainsfield Camp
Plainsfield Camp.description: Plainsfield Camp is a possible Iron Age earthwork on the Quantock Hills near Aisholt in Somerset.

Goughs Cave (Cheddar).name: Goughs Cave (Cheddar)
Goughs Cave (Cheddar).description: Cave in Somerset, open to the public.. Finds from all the caves here are in the Cheddar Caves Museum.

Wilmots Pool Cairn.name: Wilmots Pool Cairn
Wilmots Pool Cairn.description: A large 22m diameter Bronze Age barrow beside Wilmot's Pool, below Black Hill, a high point  of the Quantock Hills ridge.

Thorncombe Hill Cairns.name: Thorncombe Hill Cairns
Thorncombe Hill Cairns.description: Remains of several barrows on Thorncombe Hill, part of the Quantock Hills ridge

Thorncombe Barrow.name: Thorncombe Barrow
Thorncombe Barrow.description: Large 17m diameter bowl barrow on Thorncombe Hill high above the Trendle Ring at the top of the Quantock Hills ridge

Black Down barrows (Mendip).name: Black Down barrows (Mendip)
Black Down barrows (Mendip).description: Three bronze age round barrows sit on top of the western end of the Black Down ridge, the highest part of the Mendip Hills in Somerset.

Beacon Batch.name: Beacon Batch
Beacon Batch.description: Ten round barrows sit on top of Beacon Batch, the highest point of the Mendip Hills in Somerset.

Bat's Castle.name: Bat's Castle
Bat's Castle.description: Hillfort in Somerset. Bat's Castle is on the hill behind (ie west of) Dunster's charming medieval stone castle, itself beside Dunster's modern town centre. It's probably about a 10 - 15 minutes walk up the hill towards this ancient hill-fort (and also some Cromwellian artillery ramparts - from where Parliamentary forces bombarded Dunster's stone castle and town centre in the 1640s English civil war). Bat's Castle is circular with rough stone walls, with some of its layout suggesting parts of it might have been used to corral animals in during both peace & war.

East Pinford (NW).name: East Pinford (NW)
East Pinford (NW).description: This stone setting in the wilds of Exmoor is a lovely 6 stone rectangle, or two rows of three stones arranged like the dots on a domino.

Stanton Drew.name: Stanton Drew
Stanton Drew.description: At Stanton Drew village to the south of Bristol are the remains of several megalithic monuments, which once must have been an incredibly important centre. The remaining components include three large stone circles, two of which have associated avenues, and a cove. The great stone circle is the second largest in England, smaller only than the Avebury great circle.

St. Agnes Well.name: St. Agnes Well
St. Agnes Well.description: This is a delightful find, resembling many such sites encountered in Cornwall, the  author of a book of Somerset Holy wells (Horne) describes it as "the most beautiful of the Holy wells of Somerset".

Whirley Pool.name: Whirley Pool
Whirley Pool.description: This site is an interesting potential ancient watering hole. It is now a pool surrounded by alder trees with a constant bubbling action. Before the railway tapped its water in the 1880s, the water was so powerful that it sent jets of water into the air.

Tarr Steps Prehistoric Bridge.name: Tarr Steps Prehistoric Bridge
Tarr Steps Prehistoric Bridge.description: A (possibly) prehistoric bridge over the river Barle near Winsford. It is certainly Medieval and a much older date back to 1000 BC or beyond seems entirely possible. Some of the stones weigh 5 tons and were said to have been placed there by the Devil to win a bet.

Bristol City Museum.name: Bristol City Museum
Bristol City Museum.description: Bristol City Museum and Art Gallery is located in a splendid building at the top of Park Street, which includes a fine archaeological collection from the region.

Priddy Nine Barrows.name: Priddy Nine Barrows
Priddy Nine Barrows.description: Barrow Cemetery in Somerset. There are actually 17 barrows in this extensive cemetery which is arranged over two low ridges, so appearing all along the skyline if you stand in the right place. Access is good from several points, with the barrows standing in pasture.

Charterhouse Earthwork.name: Charterhouse Earthwork
Charterhouse Earthwork.description: Large circular Earthwork on the hillside above the Charterhouse settlement, fort and lead mines. It is the remains of an amphitheatre built in Roman times for the entertainment of the people of the Charterhouse settlement. However, it is possible that it was constructed on the site of a much more ancient henge monument.

Glastonbury Stone Circle.name: Glastonbury Stone Circle
Glastonbury Stone Circle.description: The Glastonbury Festival stone circle is a recent monument on the British landscape, yet it is one that is visited by huge numbers of people over a very short period of time.  Estimates of the numbers of people gathering at the Glastonbury stone circle are subject to speculation, however with a large proportion of the hundreds of thousands of people at festival visiting the stone circle its influence and draw is undisputed.

Avalon Marshes Visitor Centre.name: Avalon Marshes Visitor Centre
Avalon Marshes Visitor Centre.description: The Avalon Marshes Centre in Somerset lies close to all the Avalon Marshes nature reserves. There are new replica sections of prehistoric trackway along the route of the Sweet Track on Shapwick Heath National Nature Reserve.

Battery Point.name: Battery Point
Battery Point.description: A nice stone with many fossilised shells to be seen within it, stands strategically at Battery Point, Portishead, as the Seafarers Memorial Stone, a memorial to seafarers of the west country.

Eastwood Fort, Portishead.name: Eastwood Fort, Portishead
Eastwood Fort, Portishead.description: Ancient woodland covered limestone hill, now a nature reserve, to the north of Portishead, beside the shipping channel into Portbury and Avonmouth docks, and the river Avon up to Bristol. As such has been an important strategic place since history began.

West Hill Fort, Portishead.name: West Hill Fort, Portishead
West Hill Fort, Portishead.description: Site of univallate banked fort / camp enclosure. Overlooks "King Road" navigation and mouth to former Portishead Pill sheltered anchorage or berthage (now Portishead locked Dock). Elements of bank still visible on NW wooded aspect.

Lype Hill Barrows.name: Lype Hill Barrows
Lype Hill Barrows.description: A pair of Bronze age bowl barrows on Lype Hill, Exmoor.

Sweetworthy settlement.name: Sweetworthy settlement
Sweetworthy settlement.description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Somerset

Wain's Hill.name: Wain's Hill
Wain's Hill.description: Remains of an Iron Age Hill / Promontory Fort on Wain's Hill at the south western end of the rocky hill to the west of delightful Clevedon town.

Rolstone.name: Rolstone
Rolstone.description: Stone is in a field off of Silver Moor Lane. This can be reached via Woolvers Hill Road near the village of Banwell, North Somerset.

Stanton Drew Great Circle.name: Stanton Drew Great Circle
Stanton Drew Great Circle.description: These circles cover a large area so it is difficult to appreciate their grandeur. There are two main circles, the Great Circle, diameter 113m, and the North-east Circle (30m). The former circle is the second largest in Britain after Avebury.  There is also a SSW circle, see our separate page for this.

Priddy Circles S.name: Priddy Circles S
Priddy Circles S.description: Southern of the three main Priddy Circles, which are an arrangement of four circular earthwork enclosures near Priddy. The circles are described as 'probable Neolithic ritual or ceremonial monuments similar to a henge'. The circles, each nearly 200m across, are best seen from the air.

North Stoke Promontory Fort.name: North Stoke Promontory Fort
North Stoke Promontory Fort.description: North Stoke is a single ramparted hillfort, triangular in shape with a curved base on the east consisting of a bank and ditch terminating at the north and south on the escarpment which falls away almost precipitously.

Dunkery Beacon.name: Dunkery Beacon
Dunkery Beacon.description: Five cairns are on the summit of this highest point of Exmoor.

Battlegore.name: Battlegore
Battlegore.description: Remnants of three large round barrows and other monuments including a stone setting are to be found in the fields opposite to Danesfield School.

Priddy long barrow.name: Priddy long barrow
Priddy long barrow.description: Neolithic long barrow, excavated in 1928. A few human teeth and some flints were found, but no dating material.

Beacon Hill Platform Cairn.name: Beacon Hill Platform Cairn
Beacon Hill Platform Cairn.description: Beacon Hill Platform cairn, a large platform cairn (25m diameter) at the north-western end of the Quantock Hills ridge.

Fire Beacon Cairn.name: Fire Beacon Cairn
Fire Beacon Cairn.description: Fire Beacon Cairn on the western slope of the Quantock Hills above Crowcombe comprises a stony circular mound, 25.5m in diameter and 1.5m high.

West Hill Platform Cairn.name: West Hill Platform Cairn
West Hill Platform Cairn.description: A massive platform cairn on the ridge of the Quantock Hills above Crowcombe.

Black Hill Tumuli.name: Black Hill Tumuli
Black Hill Tumuli.description: Remains of several barrows on Black Hill, part of the Quantock Hills ridge

Hurley Beacon Tumulus.name: Hurley Beacon Tumulus
Hurley Beacon Tumulus.description: A big platform cairn on Hurley Beacon, with stunning views.

Dead Woman's Ditch.name: Dead Woman's Ditch
Dead Woman's Ditch.description: Dead womans ditch is a prehistoric earthwork, possibly related to the nearby Dowsborough hillfort.

Wells and Mendip Museum.name: Wells and Mendip Museum
Wells and Mendip Museum.description: I spotted this old stone outside Wells and Mendip Museum while photographing the Cathedral (across the road), on a beautiful sunny evening in May 2013.

Pagans Hill.name: Pagans Hill
Pagans Hill.description: Pagans Hill is an evocative name and in this case an accurate one as excavations between 1949 and 1953 discovered - although the name is probably pure coincidence as it is believed to derive from Pegnes a local land owner.

Aveline's Hole.name: Aveline's Hole
Aveline's Hole.description: Aveline's Hole is a cave at Burrington Combe in the limestone of the Mendip Hills. The earliest scientifically dated cemetery in Britain was found at Aveline's Hole. The human bone fragments it contained, from about 21 different individuals, are thought to be between roughly 10,200 and 10,400 years old.

Great Hill Platform cairn.name: Great Hill Platform cairn
Great Hill Platform cairn.description: A very large Bronze Age platform cairn lies on the summit of Great Hill, with another platform cairn and normal little cairn just to the North East.

Wills Neck.name: Wills Neck
Wills Neck.description: There are at least six barrows on the 386m high Wills Neck, the highest place in the Quantock hills.

Glastonbury Tor milestone at Wells.name: Glastonbury Tor milestone at Wells
Glastonbury Tor milestone at Wells.description: Walking around the moated Bishops Palace at Wells in Somerset I saw this gorgeous modern stone which seemed to be marking the mileage to Glastonbury.

Culbone Stone.name: Culbone Stone
Culbone Stone.description: Heading east on the A39 Lynmouth to Porlock road, you will see a pub to your right; imminently, there is a left hand turn onto a minor road, as the main road veers right. Take this left. Soon, to your left is a parking area, with a little sign and information board for the Culbone Stone:

Batcombe Hollow north stone.name: Batcombe Hollow north stone
Batcombe Hollow north stone.description: This is one of two stones in Batcombe Hollow, above the village of Draycott, in the Mendip Hills, about five miles respectively from Cheddar and Wells. The stone is on the official West Mendip Way path.

Batcombe Hollow south standing stone.name: Batcombe Hollow south standing stone
Batcombe Hollow south standing stone.description: This standing stone lies at the southern end of Batcombe Hollow, a deep grassy combe just north of the village of Draycott, in the Mendip Hills, about five miles from Cheddar in one direction and Wells in the other. The stone is directly on the West Mendip Way path but does not appear on OS maps.

South Cadbury Castle.name: South Cadbury Castle
South Cadbury Castle.description: South Cadbury hill fort, near Sparkford in Somerset has a long history of occupation. Apart from its stunning setting, its main claim to fame is the evidence that it was reoccupied in the period after the Roman withdrawal. It has been suggested that it is the historical basis for the legend of Arthur's Camelot; indeed it is very close to the village of Queen Camel, whose name is apparently derived from "Camelot".

Lansdown Camp.name: Lansdown Camp
Lansdown Camp.description: Just northwest of Bath Racecourse lies an unusual series of earthworks which has defied all attempts of dating - no-one seems to 'stick his/her neck out' on this one - even EH (spy in the sky and all!) seems unwilling to promulgate an opinion -

St Alphages Well.name: St Alphages Well
St Alphages Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset

St Mary's Well (Charlcombe).name: St Mary's Well (Charlcombe)
St Mary's Well (Charlcombe).description: Holy Well in Somerset. Antiquarian Horne (1923) described '...an ancient Norman church, dedicated to the Blessed Virgin, and the spring, known as St Mary's Well, close at hand in the Rectory garden. It is situated in a bank, now covered with ferns, and the water flows through a pipe into a small natural basin.'

St Mary's Well (Portishead).name: St Mary's Well (Portishead)
St Mary's Well (Portishead).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset

Snake's Well and Spring.name: Snake's Well and Spring
Snake's Well and Spring.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset

Wraxall Camp.name: Wraxall Camp
Wraxall Camp.description: Iron Age earthwork in Somerset. Quite why English Heritage should name this Iron Age Defended Settlement 'Wraxall Camp' must be something of a mystery - it lies 1.5miles East of Wraxall Village but 100m North of Failand Village.

Tap's Combe Camp.name: Tap's Combe Camp
Tap's Combe Camp.description: A little known Iron Age promontory hillfort of just 2 acres is tucked away between the Somerset villages of Brockley and Backwell to the east of the tiny hamlet of Chelvey Batch

Walton-in-Gordano Banjo Enclosure.name: Walton-in-Gordano Banjo Enclosure
Walton-in-Gordano Banjo Enclosure.description: Banjo Enclosures are probably the most distinctive type of enclosure found in the British Countryside but have only been recognised as a separate type of enclosure since the advent of sustained archaeological aerial surveys, which became more commonplace in the 1960s as a reliable form of analysis.

Tickenham Court Barrow.name: Tickenham Court Barrow
Tickenham Court Barrow.description: Measuring 10m in diameter and just 1.5m high this late Bronze Age Bowl Barrow first came into the modern 'public eye' during surveying for the M5 in the 1960s although to be fair to LV Grinsell he gave it a passing glance in 1953 -

Cadbury Camp.name: Cadbury Camp
Cadbury Camp.description: From the ramparts of the Iron Age hill fort of Cadbury Camp you get a clear impression of the immense double earthworks and ditch with a steep drop down to the Somerset levels, making this a well defended site.

Bathampton Camp.name: Bathampton Camp
Bathampton Camp.description: This early univallate Iron Age Hillfort of some 80 acres, as often happens when the archaeologists are bewildered, has been the subject of much debate over the last two hundred years - the camp is essentially rectangular, orientated East to West and is bordered on the West North and East sides by the meandering River Avon - just North of the river stands the famous Solsbury Hill - to the east the famous Bath Stone quarries have 'eaten' into the camp -

Hautville's Quoit.name: Hautville's Quoit
Hautville's Quoit.description: Late neolithic remnant of possible chambered tomb. Located NNE of Stanton Drew Great Circle, it aligns with the centre of the Great Circle and the SW Circle. It is possibly part of a larger, now destroyed, structure.

Stanton Drew NE Avenue.name: Stanton Drew NE Avenue
Stanton Drew NE Avenue.description: Avenue of stones leading in an easterly direction from the NE Stone Circle to what is thought to once be the edge of a possible lake, on the floodplain of the river Chew.

Felton Common Suck Stone.name: Felton Common Suck Stone
Felton Common Suck Stone.description: There really are no limits to the lengths Megalithic Portal contributors will go to seek out lost sites - take this site - it is scarcely mentioned in Somerset archaeological history.

Small Down Camp.name: Small Down Camp
Small Down Camp.description: Small Down Camp is an Iron Age multivallate hillfort covering 2.0 ha. The best preserved part of the earthworks is at the south, where three lines of ramparts and ditches are perfectly visible.

Dundry Long Barrow.name: Dundry Long Barrow
Dundry Long Barrow.description: It is now probable that this site is accepted as a Long Barrow rather than two Round Barrows despite it being waisted and much affected by the plough - it sits just on the south side of a strong ridge overlooking the southern suburbs of Bristol - the views from the ridge are quite amazing - it measures 75ft by 30ft and is 4ft high and is orientated E-W - there is no ditch - this and its shorter length are common features of many Somerset Long Barrows

Felton Village Bowl Barrow.name: Felton Village Bowl Barrow
Felton Village Bowl Barrow.description: Lurking just to the North of the road between Lulsgate Bottom (on the A38) and Winford (E towards Chew Magna) (West Lane) is a very well preserved Bowl Barrow which was 'totally missed' by the University of Bristol Spelaeological Society expert E K Tratman and his more illustrious 1950s critic the famed Glanville - it was first reported to the Ordnance Survey by S A Rahtz who frequently disagreed with them both -

Felton Hill Bowl Barrow T30A.name: Felton Hill Bowl Barrow T30A
Felton Hill Bowl Barrow T30A.description: This site invites you to be somewhat wary of 1925/55 archaeologists or even sceptical - two barrows have been 'placed' at the same site (NOT to be confused with T28 & T29 200x to the westsouthwest which have confluent ditches)

Felton Hill Long Barrow T26.name: Felton Hill Long Barrow T26
Felton Hill Long Barrow T26.description: Felton Common is a large open space on land fairly high up just to the east of Bristol airport with lots of odd stones, mounds and other features. At the southwestern corner are the remains of an oval barrow, which has several stones protruding from its northern end, which may be the remains of what was once a chamber.

Solsbury Hill.name: Solsbury Hill
Solsbury Hill.description: A univallate hillfort above Bath, and probably the only hillfort that has a well known song named after it. There is a good view down to the city, hence Peter Gabriel's lyric "Climbing up on Solsbury Hill, I could see the city light".

Tynings Farm Barrow Group.name: Tynings Farm Barrow Group
Tynings Farm Barrow Group.description: A well-preserved Late Bronze Age barrow cemetery is located SE of Shipham. It consists of ditched round barrows in which cremation burials were discovered.

Stantonbury Camp.name: Stantonbury Camp
Stantonbury Camp.description: Remains of an Iron Age hillfort on a flat-topped hill in north Somerset.

Glastonbury Tor.name: Glastonbury Tor
Glastonbury Tor.description: Glastonbury Tor is a sacred hill near Glastonbury in England which features the roofless St. Michael's Tower. The site is managed by the National Trust. The Tor has a striking location in the middle of a plain called the Summerland Meadows, part of the Somerset Levels.

Bathampton.name: Bathampton
Bathampton.description: Possible stone circle in Somerset. There is now nothing to see on the surface to suggest the former presence of stone circles or avenues in the area, we have only the word of an antiquarian of the mid nineteenth century (Scarth, 1857), writing in a paper about other archaeological features.

Stanton Drew NE Circle.name: Stanton Drew NE Circle
Stanton Drew NE Circle.description: Smaller stone circle outliying the huge great circle at Stanton Drew by about 100 metres to the northeast.

Burwalls Camp.name: Burwalls Camp
Burwalls Camp.description: The Burwalls Camp hillfort is one of three iron age forts here probably guarding a ford crossing of the river Avon at the bottom of the Avon Gorge, below where is now the Clifton Suspension Bridge.

Ham Hill (Somerset).name: Ham Hill (Somerset)
Ham Hill (Somerset).description: A Hillfort in Somerset: probably the largest in Britain. The outer ramparts on Ham Hill form a three mile long defensive perimeter around one of the largest Iron Age hillforts in Britain. The interior has been quarried since Roman times  for its honey-coloured Hamstone giving it a peculiar lumpy topography.

Worlebury Camp.name: Worlebury Camp
Worlebury Camp.description:
On the hill that overlooks Weston-super-Mare  there are 
the remains of Worlebury hillfort, described by James Dyer as 'one of the most notable hillforts in Somerset'.

Priddy Circles C.name: Priddy Circles C
Priddy Circles C.description: Central of the three main Priddy Circles, which are an arrangement of four circular earthwork enclosures near Priddy. The circles are described as 'probable Neolithic ritual or ceremonial monuments similar to a henge'. The circles, each nearly 200m across, are best seen from the air.

Lime House Long Barrow.name: Lime House Long Barrow
Lime House Long Barrow.description: Just to the southwest of central Chewton Mendip, up onto the higher meadows, there is a large and overgrown lumpy and bumpy area, which was once a fairly large long barrow.

Castle Farm Long Barrow.name: Castle Farm Long Barrow
Castle Farm Long Barrow.description: In a strip of conifers to the south of Castle Farm, there's remains of a longbarrow in amongst the trees just to the east of the busy B3134. Looking from the roadside, I am willing to believe its still in there, as the ferns seemed to suggest there is a raise in the ground level.

Priddy Circles.name: Priddy Circles
Priddy Circles.description: Priddy Circles are an arrangement of four circular earthwork enclosures near Priddy. The circles are described as 'probable Neolithic ritual or ceremonial monuments similar to a henge'. The circles, each nearly 200m across, are best seen from the air.

Cheriton Ridge Boundary stones.name: Cheriton Ridge Boundary stones
Cheriton Ridge Boundary stones.description: The border between Devon and Somerset across Cheriton Ridge is marked with an old boundary wall, and a more modern wire fence. Approaching from the south, there is a point partway down the western hillside where it looks like there is a place to cross. Indeed there is, and there are two lovely old standing stones here, each about 5 feet tall, and looking very gnarled.

Hoaroak stones.name: Hoaroak stones
Hoaroak stones.description: The stones here were very hard to find among the long couch grass on the fairly steep side of the hill. This would be a very wet area if it hadnt been so dry for so long, as it seems to be an area where lots of water runs off from the top of the hill.

Barrow at Rowberrow.name: Barrow at Rowberrow
Barrow at Rowberrow.description: Bronze Age Barrow at Rowberrow (NOT Rowberrow Barrow, which isn't at Rowberrow!) in Somerset

Backwell Cave.name: Backwell Cave
Backwell Cave.description: Cave or Rock Shelter in Somerset

Charterhouse settlement.name: Charterhouse settlement
Charterhouse settlement.description: Roman Fortlet and settlement, part of the Roman lead mine and Roman mining settlement at Charterhouse AD 49

Gorsey Bigbury Henge.name: Gorsey Bigbury Henge
Gorsey Bigbury Henge.description: Listed on the O S map, sheet 141 as a Henge, this henge is approx 40 meters in diameter and looks very similar in construction to the henge at ST558497. (Drove Cottage Henge)

Hoar Moor (E).name: Hoar Moor (E)
Hoar Moor (E).description: Standing Stone on Exmoor. This stone is quite large (for Exmoor) lump of hard grey stone. It is more than a metre long and pointed at the top, 30 cm wide at the base, and with a thickness of about 20cm. The stone is leaning so much that it is almost flat to the ground, but it is still very firmly in place.

Peat Moors Centre.name: Peat Moors Centre
Peat Moors Centre.description: Museum in Somerset (now closed). Reconstructions of many prehistoric structures including Iron Age roundhouses and prehistoric trackways.

Brean Down.name: Brean Down
Brean Down.description: Brean Down is a promontory that marks the end of the Mendip hills. The top is about 100m above the sea and over looks Brean to the south and Weston-Super-Mare to the north. There is evidence of ancient field systems and barrows and a small iron Age Hill Fort on it.

Stanton Drew - The Cove.name: Stanton Drew - The Cove
Stanton Drew - The Cove.description: Standing Stones in Somerset. Situated in the garden of 'The Druid's Arms' pub. The name is derived from the landowners, the Drew family, as is the name of the village.

Chalice Well.name: Chalice Well
Chalice Well.description: Holy Well / Spring in Somerset. Chalice Well's famous iron-red water is never failing and is known as the Blood Spring. Nearby in Well House Lane is the White Spring.

White Spring (Somerset).name: White Spring (Somerset)
White Spring (Somerset).description: Nineteenth century well house built to provide water for the local population.  The area was said to be a well known beauty spot before the well house was built.  It has been converted into a Pagan temple and is manned by volunteers.  Inside is candlelit with shrines and a bathing pool which is used.  If visiting bare in mind that there might be people bathing inside. No photography allowed inside the well house.  The floor is very wet so take care when looking around. Check website as ceremonies take place throughout the year.

Athelney.name: Athelney
Athelney.description: The Isle of Athelney is the lowest known Hillfort in the United Kingdom. There is evidence of Iron Age and Bronze age occupation, as well as it being the place famous for King Alfred's stand against the Viking invaders (and the legend of burning his cakes).

Trout Hill 1.name: Trout Hill 1
Trout Hill 1.description: My notes say that this was once a quincunx that now has four stones, with three still standing and one fallen.

Trout Hill 2.name: Trout Hill 2
Trout Hill 2.description: My notes say that this was once a quincunx with four stones still standing fairly recently. What I found in the long grass was only three stones still standing, but that is not to say there arent any others hidden under the long undergrowth.

Patwell.name: Patwell
Patwell.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset. This fine ancient structure still exists over the bridge from the church, at the start of Patwell Lane. However it can often be obscured by a parked car.

Holy Well (Edington).name: Holy Well (Edington)
Holy Well (Edington).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset

Holy Well (West Coker).name: Holy Well (West Coker)
Holy Well (West Coker).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset

St Ann's Well (Brislington).name: St Ann's Well (Brislington)
St Ann's Well (Brislington).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Bristol. Located in a public park is one of the cities few surviving and doubtlessly most famed Holy wells. Now remarkably like a green oasis in some of the worst areas of industrialised Bristol is St Anne's wood, which was acquired by the Bristol Corporation, and since then very little has been done thankfully to change its situation.

St. Leonard's Well (Dunster).name: St. Leonard's Well (Dunster)
St. Leonard's Well (Dunster).description: Holy Well  in Somerset. Tucked up an ancient cobbled lane which becomes increasingly muddy even in the height of summer is this noted well. It is believed to be of 14th-15th century construction, and formed the supply for the ancient town priory (now ruinous). It is mentioned in records of Edward III and Henry IV reign as "Fontem sancti Leonardi".

St. Catherine's Well (Swell).name: St. Catherine's Well (Swell)
St. Catherine's Well (Swell).description: Holy Well in Somerset. This delightful wayside well was apparently rediscovered in the 1980s by two local people. It is recorded by both antiquarian Horne and Tongue but thought lost.

Pixy Well.name: Pixy Well
Pixy Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset

Devil's Whispering Well.name: Devil's Whispering Well
Devil's Whispering Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset

Sacred Spring, Bath.name: Sacred Spring, Bath
Sacred Spring, Bath.description: Sacred Spring in Somerset. The hot spring at Bath was a sacred place long before the Romans came. it was channeled by the Romans and later made into a fashionable spa, yet still the hot water bubbles to the surface.

Harters Hill.name: Harters Hill
Harters Hill.description: Ritual Alignment in Somerset. Harters Hill excavation - The remains of a late Bronze Age ritual alignment of oak piles and small stakes surrounded by masses of worked wood, that was built in a wetland in 1076 BC.

Sweet Track.name: Sweet Track
Sweet Track.description: Ancient Trackway in Somerset. The Sweet Track is a supreme, if not so obvious example of Neolithic engineering, 6000 years old. An elevated footpath that ran for almost 2km across the Somerset levels swamps.

Beckham Hill.name: Beckham Hill
Beckham Hill.description: This Exmoor stone setting is stated to consist of three rows of three stones, with only 3 stones still standing, which is fairly accurate except that I could only find 8 stones in total.

Swap Hill.name: Swap Hill
Swap Hill.description: Before visiting this Exmoor stone setting, I took a few notes from various sources, as often they are hard to find, and not what they at first appear. For this, my notes said that there are 5 large stones in a kite shape, with two still standing.

Elworthy Barrows hillfort.name: Elworthy Barrows hillfort
Elworthy Barrows hillfort.description: Partial remains of a roughly circular hillfort defended by a bank and ditch, at the eastern end of the Brendon Hills in Somerset.

Naked Boy stone.name: Naked Boy stone
Naked Boy stone.description: Standing Stone, marked on maps as a boundary stone, on top of the Brendon Hills in Somerset.

Wiveliscombe Barrow.name: Wiveliscombe Barrow
Wiveliscombe Barrow.description: Large, well preserved bowl barrow 21m diameter, 2m high, on top of the Brendon Hills  in Somerset.

Long Holcombe (S).name: Long Holcombe (S)
Long Holcombe (S).description: This stone is not easy to find, despite it being just four hundred metres to the north east of the ridge top road near Long Holcombe Cross. It is found in open access land near to the head of the valley on the southern side, and well below the skyline. Walking to the stone from a gateway at the south western entrance to this piece of moorland was across some very wet and boggy ground.

Swap Hill (N).name: Swap Hill (N)
Swap Hill (N).description: Standing stone on Exmoor, probably once part of a stone setting.

Lanacombe 4.name: Lanacombe 4
Lanacombe 4.description: Stone setting on Exmoor, perhaps a stone row, consisting of 5 stones.

Lanacombe 5.name: Lanacombe 5
Lanacombe 5.description: On the south facing slopes of Lanacombe Hill on Exmoor, above the stream valley, are the remains of this recently found stone setting.

Trout Hill 3.name: Trout Hill 3
Trout Hill 3.description: My notes say that there are four stones, one standing and three fallen, for this stone setting on the eastern edges of Trout Hill.

Withypool Hill Barrow.name: Withypool Hill Barrow
Withypool Hill Barrow.description: This is large 25 metre diameter round barrow on the top of Withypool Hill. Its been much dug about in the middle but is still well over a metre high. The outside circumference is still in very good condition, and almost looks like it had a ditch and outer bank around it originally.

Withypool Circle.name: Withypool Circle
Withypool Circle.description: This little known stone circle on Withypool Hill in Exmoor national park is a delight to find and visit, despite the stones being small and hard to find.

Porlock Circle.name: Porlock Circle
Porlock Circle.description: The Porlock Allotment Circle is a much damaged stone circle on Exmoor in Somerset.  It can be found just behind the hedge to the west of the minor road from the A39 to Exford, not far south from the Whit Stones.

Whit Stones.name: Whit Stones
Whit Stones.description: A Pair of Standing Stones on Exmoor, in Somerset. These two sizeable stones, possibly barrow remnants, situated a couple miles west of Porlock, and several miles east of Lynton, are easily accessible.

Wambarrows.name: Wambarrows
Wambarrows.description: There are three large barrows in an east-west line on top of Winsford Hill, known as the Wambarrows. The western barrow, furthest from the trig point at the top of the hill is perhaps the largest, almost 30 metres in diameter but less well defined and more overgrown than the other two.

Skipperhams Well.name: Skipperhams Well
Skipperhams Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset

Axbridge Church Wells.name: Axbridge Church Wells
Axbridge Church Wells.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset

St Pancras Well.name: St Pancras Well
St Pancras Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset

St Decumen's Well.name: St Decumen's Well
St Decumen's Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset.

Pen Hill Longbarrow.name: Pen Hill Longbarrow
Pen Hill Longbarrow.description: This is a 45 metre long by 15 metre wide longbarrow which is to be found in a little fenced enclosure, just to the south of the summit of Pen Hill at the southern edge of the Mendip Hills just north of Wells.

Shad Well.name: Shad Well
Shad Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset.

St Andrew's Well (Corton Denham).name: St Andrew's Well (Corton Denham)
St Andrew's Well (Corton Denham).description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset.

St Barbara's Well.name: St Barbara's Well
St Barbara's Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset.

St Andrew's Well (Stogursey).name: St Andrew's Well (Stogursey)
St Andrew's Well (Stogursey).description: Holy Well in Somerset. Down this side lane one is greeted with the most impressive structure surrounding a Holy Well in Somerset. One enters a large archway into a forecourt where two small 'brick huts' are apparent (now with windows) within which apparently the waters arise and perhaps custodians sat.

Priddy Circles N.name: Priddy Circles N
Priddy Circles N.description: Northern of the three main Priddy Circles, which are an arrangement of four circular earthwork enclosures near Priddy. The circles are described as 'probable Neolithic ritual or ceremonial monuments similar to a henge'. The circles, each nearly 200m across, are best seen from the air.

Fernhill Farm.name: Fernhill Farm
Fernhill Farm.description: Modern Stone Circle in Somerset. Since 1994 the Big Green Gathering has developed in to the main 'green' event in Britain, if not the world. It has showcased future technologies, alternative ways of life and inspired many town folk to adopt a more sustainable lifestyle.

King Arthur's Well.name: King Arthur's Well
King Arthur's Well.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset

Queen Anne's Well, Cadbury Castle.name: Queen Anne's Well, Cadbury Castle
Queen Anne's Well, Cadbury Castle.description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Somerset

Ston Easton Barrow.name: Ston Easton Barrow
Ston Easton Barrow.description: Beside the A37, just to the north of the village of Ston Easton is to be seen this nice round barrow, in a field just beside the road, at a crossing of farm tracks.

Cadbury Hill.name: Cadbury Hill
Cadbury Hill.description: Cadbury Hill Fort is situated on top of Cadbury Hill just outside of Yatton, in Somerset.

Abbot's Way.name: Abbot's Way
Abbot's Way.description: A Neolithic Trackway in Somerset, the photo is of a reconstruction that was at the

Huish Champflower Barrow.name: Huish Champflower Barrow
Huish Champflower Barrow.description: Round Barrow on top of the Brendon Hills in Somerset.

Omphalos Stone (Glastonbury Abbey).name: Omphalos Stone (Glastonbury Abbey)
Omphalos Stone (Glastonbury Abbey).description: Natural Stone / Glacial Erratic in Somerset

Giants Grave, Southmead.name: Giants Grave, Southmead
Giants Grave, Southmead.description: There is nothing to be seen of this Long Barrow, permission must be sought from the farm called Southmead Farm. She is quite happy to help.

Fry's Well.name: Fry's Well
Fry's Well.description: Fry's Well stands beside the footpath of one of the main streets in Chilcompton. Its plaque reads "Fry's Well c.1700 Renovated 1987".

Culbone Hill.name: Culbone Hill
Culbone Hill.description: A stone row consisting of a possible 21 stones with intermittent gaps suggesting robbing. The monument is of Bronze Age date and the stones range in height from 0.2m to 0.6m.

Wook's Quoit.name: Wook's Quoit
Wook's Quoit.description: In a field belonging to Yarberry farm, the 8ft tall stone is of the same material as the Stanton Drew stones and the Wimble Stone.

The Devil's Bed and Bolster.name: The Devil's Bed and Bolster
The Devil's Bed and Bolster.description: Long Mound with Chambered Tomb in Somerset. The wonderfully named Devil's Bed and Bolster comprises a badly disturbed long mound littered with more than 20 sarsen stones and some 8 or 9 stones forming possibly 2 or 3 chambers which are still in situ.

Felton Bowl Barrows T28 &amp; T29.name: Felton Bowl Barrows T28 & T29
Felton Bowl Barrows T28 &amp; T29.description: Felton Common is a large open space on land fairly high up just to the east of Bristol airport with lots of odd stones, mounds and other features. Near the southern edge of the common can be found a couple of large mounds, with many stones and rocks to be seen, but it is difficult to know what to make of these remains, which are to be found amongst the deep undergrowth.

Brent Knoll Camp.name: Brent Knoll Camp
Brent Knoll Camp.description: This wonderful steep sided, flat topped hill rises 450 feet out of the Somerset Levels not far from the sea in Bridgwater Bay. Legend has it that it was created by the Devil when he was carving out Cheddar Gorge, and threw a handful of rock out towards the sea. Geology has it that this limestone outcrop of the Mendip hills dates from the Jurassic times of 300 million years ago. Personally, I always think it looks like the hill out of Close Encounters, and is a landing pad for Alien craft !

Ashen Hill Barrows.name: Ashen Hill Barrows
Ashen Hill Barrows.description: Barrow Cemetery of eight round barrows in Somerset

St Andrew's Well (Wells).name: St Andrew's Well (Wells)
St Andrew's Well (Wells).description: Holy Well in Somerset. St Andrews Well behind Wells Cathedral can be spotted through a peep hole in a high stone wall.  The water from the well is channelled away to a subterranean dipping chamber and then on through the Market Square gutters.

Almsworthy.name: Almsworthy
Almsworthy.description: This is stated by various sources to be the remains of two concentric ovals, or up to six lines of stones, but I could see no particular pattern. Many stones have perhaps been removed for walls etc, leaving just a scattering remaining.

Pool Farm Cist.name: Pool Farm Cist
Pool Farm Cist.description: Cup and Ring Marked Stone in Somerset

Fairy Toot.name: Fairy Toot
Fairy Toot.description: The once massive Fairy Toot long barrow near Nempnett Thrubwell in North Somerset is now all but totally destroyed. The original size was about 60m long, 25m wide, on a north-south axis.

Maes Knoll.name: Maes Knoll
Maes Knoll.description: The remains of this Iron age hillfort lie at the eastern end of the Dundry Hill ridge just to the south of Bristol.

Butcombe Barrow.name: Butcombe Barrow
Butcombe Barrow.description: This impressively situated bowl barrow lies just below the top of a hillock near Bicknell Farm, with splendid views south over Blagdon Lake to the Mendip Hills, and west to the sea.

Deerleap Stones.name: Deerleap Stones
Deerleap Stones.description: Pair of standing stones on the edge of the Mendip Hills in Somerset

Compton Bishop.name: Compton Bishop
Compton Bishop.description: Pair of Standing Stones in Somerset

Cheddar Museum of Prehistory.name: Cheddar Museum of Prehistory
Cheddar Museum of Prehistory.description: Museum within which many of the finds from the Cheddar Caves and the skeleton of Cheddar Man are displayed.

Portbury.name: Portbury
Portbury.description: Stone of about 1.8 metres height standing on a little patch of grass between the school building and the church at Portbury, just off the main road to the north towards the M5.

Caratacus Stone.name: Caratacus Stone
Caratacus Stone.description: Caratacus stone, Winsford Hill. SS 88983355 The inscription reads CARAACI NEPUS, kinsman of Caratacus. The stone originally lay close to a track running out of the Exe valley.

Orchardleigh Stones.name: Orchardleigh Stones
Orchardleigh Stones.description: This site was excavated by H St George Gray, the archaeologist fanous for his work at Avebury and Arbor Low, in 1921. It is composed of a low mound with two stones, one of which is broken, at the eastern end. The remains of other stones found during the excavation can be seen to the west.

Priddy Circles Unfinished N.name: Priddy Circles Unfinished N
Priddy Circles Unfinished N.description: Unfinished circular henge style earthwork monument just to the north of the three main Priddy Rings, on top of the Mendip Hills in Somerset.

Glastonbury Lake Village.name: Glastonbury Lake Village
Glastonbury Lake Village.description: Ancient Village in Somerset. Very little remains of this Iron Age Lake Village, which is owned by the Glastonbury Antiquarian Society, but many of the finds from the site are on display in the

Stoney Littleton.name: Stoney Littleton
Stoney Littleton.description: James Dyer describes the Stoney Littleton long barrow as "the most notable chambered long-barrow in south-western England" - and I agree with him! It is simply superb. About 30m in length and 15m wide at the south-east end, it stands nearly 3m high. There is a horned entrance with a magical ammonite cast on the western door-jamb. This fossil must have been found and specially placed here as something of real significance. Was it seen as a stone serpent or perhaps such fossils gave rise to legends of dragons? The entrance leads to a gallery 16m long, but only 1m high. A torch is required to look into the three pairs of side chambers and an end chamber.

Porlock Allotment NE.name: Porlock Allotment NE
Porlock Allotment NE.description: About 0.7 kilometres walk to the west of the stone circle, across rough moorland, just above the place where the two streams which surround the circle meet, is marked a cairn and stones. Although it is in quite a prominent position, it was not easy to find amongst all the bracken and heather, and not at all visible from the ground between it and the circle.

Wookey Hole Caves.name: Wookey Hole Caves
Wookey Hole Caves.description: Cave or Rock Shelter in Somerset

Trendle Ring.name: Trendle Ring
Trendle Ring.description: Hillslope Enclosure dating to the Iron Age in Somerset

Stokeleigh Camp.name: Stokeleigh Camp
Stokeleigh Camp.description: Iron age promontary hillfort on a spur overlooking the Avon Gorge from the high plateau at the western side of the Gorge, now a part of the large Leigh Woods nature reserve. This is one of three iron age forts here probably guarding a ford crossing of the river Avon at the bottom of the Avon Gorge, below where is now the Clifton Suspension Bridge.

Robin Hood's Butts South.name: Robin Hood's Butts South
Robin Hood's Butts South.description: Barrow Cemetery of four round barrows in Somerset

Robin Hood's Butts North.name: Robin Hood's Butts North
Robin Hood's Butts North.description: Barrow Cemetery of five round barrows in Somerset

Maesbury Castle.name: Maesbury Castle
Maesbury Castle.description: This small univallate ring hillfort stands at 291 metres above sea level on the edge of the Mendip Hills in Somerset

Robin How.name: Robin How
Robin How.description: One of a number of cairns on Dunkery Hill in Somerset

Museum of Somerset.name: Museum of Somerset
Museum of Somerset.description: The Museum of Somerset tells the county's story from prehistoric times to the present day using real objects combined with evocative films, sounds and images, and the voices and words of Somerset people past and present.

Hoscombe SE.name: Hoscombe SE
Hoscombe SE.description: A Row of Three Stones (Alignment) in Somerset, one of which has fallen.

Coley Water, South.name: Coley Water, South
Coley Water, South.description: A Row of Four Stones (Alignment) in Somerset, three of which have fallen

Lanacombe 2.name: Lanacombe 2
Lanacombe 2.description: On the south facing slopes of Lanacombe Hill on Exmoor, are the remains of this stone setting which is said to be 4 stones in a row.

Madacombe.name: Madacombe
Madacombe.description: This is a 286 metre long row of 12 stones, very well hidden under the Exmoor heather, and not easy to find.

Chains Valley.name: Chains Valley
Chains Valley.description: A triple stone row measuring 66mm long, including 13 small and medium-sized stones situated on a north facing slope.

Wilmersham Common South.name: Wilmersham Common South
Wilmersham Common South.description: Stone row composed mainly of tiny stones which barely protrude through the surface.

Toms Hill.name: Toms Hill
Toms Hill.description: This stone setting in the wilds of Exmoor is a 6 stone rectangle, or two rows of three stones arranged like the dots on a domino.

Squallacombe Centre.name: Squallacombe Centre
Squallacombe Centre.description: A wide double stone row (or avenue) measuring up to 19.5m long, including 8 small and medium-sized stones situated on a gentle east facing slope.

Porlock Common SW.name: Porlock Common SW
Porlock Common SW.description: Remains of a double Stone Row on Porlock Common, on Exmoor.

Lanacombe 3.name: Lanacombe 3
Lanacombe 3.description: Much dilapidated stone setting towards the eastern end of Lanacombe, on Exmoor in Somerset.

Lanacombe 1.name: Lanacombe 1
Lanacombe 1.description: This stone setting is more nearly on the ridgetop of Lanacombe Hill, with super views to the south and east. My notes I had with me told me that there are 13 stones, with two fallen.

Barrow House Farm Long Barrow.name: Barrow House Farm Long Barrow
Barrow House Farm Long Barrow.description: Just to the west of the A39, on the top of the hill just before it descends southwards into Chewton Mendip, there are some lumps and bumps which can be seen in the field. It looks to be two or three round barrows with a fairly large long barrow in between them. The long barrow possibly has remains of a chamber at its eastern end.

Leigh Down.name: Leigh Down
Leigh Down.description: Stone Circle in Somerset. Pretty much gone, a couple of stones can still be seen, but it's open to question if it ever was a circle in the first place

Chew Stoke.name: Chew Stoke
Chew Stoke.description: Destroyed stone circle once supposed to have stood near where the Methodist church is now built. Some stones were to be found laying in the hedge nearby in the last century.

Drove Cottage Henge.name: Drove Cottage Henge
Drove Cottage Henge.description: A 55 metre diameter henge which can be seen in a field to the south of Hillgorve Road to the north of Wells, and to the east of Priddy.

Stanton Drew - Avenue.name: Stanton Drew - Avenue
Stanton Drew - Avenue.description: Avenue of stones leading in an East North Easterly direction from the Great Circle to what is thought to once be the edge of a possible lake, on the floodplain of the river Chew.
